awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding for U.S.-based participants, including members of underrepresented groups in the mathematical sciences, to participate in the conference "Young Mathematicians in C*-Algebras (YMC*A)", held August 8-12, 2022 at the University of Oslo, Norway. This meeting is organized for and by graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in operator algebras and related areas, with the goal of fostering scientific and social interaction between early-career researchers. In each of its previous six editions, YMC*A has provided an excellent opportunity for over one hundred early-career operator algebraists from around the world to attend mini-courses on current research topics in operator algebras. Networking opportunities at the 2022 edition of the conference are supported by a panel discussion, open to all participants, which covers career advice and issues of equity and by informal mathematical discussions throughout the duration of the meeting.

The conference focuses on recent developments in operator algebras, noncommutative geometry, and related areas of mathematical analysis, with a particular emphasis on the interplay between operator algebras and the fields of K-theory, harmonic analysis, and quantization. The conference features three mini-courses by established researchers alongside many contributed talks by participants, and mentoring activities designed to increase retention of underrepresented groups in operator algebras. More information about the conference is available at: https://ymcstara.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Young Mathematicians in C*-algebras (YMC*A) conference was held at the University of Oslo, Norway during August 8-12, 2022. This grant provided funding for US-based early-career researchers to attend the conference, and thereby interact scientifically and socially with their European counterparts. In particular, as YMC*A is run by and for early-career operator algebraists, it provides a welcoming environment for researchers at this early career stage to talk about their work and form an international network. This project built on the funding provided by the NSF in 2020 for US-based researchers to attend YMC*A 2021.

Twenty-five researchers applied for travel support, and this NSF award funded 19 US-based participants, 5 of whom identify as women or non-binary people and 3 as Hispanic or Latino. NSF funding is crucial to the presence of US-researchers at YMC*A; in 2017, when no NSF funding was available, only 5 US-based researchers attended YMC*A. Only 2 of those 5 US-researchers were graduate students.

The exit survey for the NSF-funded participants for this 2022 conference (to which 12 of the 19 funded participants responded) provided significant evidence that YMC*A achieves the goals mentioned in the first paragraph. All 12 respondents strongly agreed that YMC*A increased their network of contacts within the operator algebras community, and all 12 respondents agreed that YMC*A increased their awareness of research trends in operator algebras. Moreover, 8 of the 12 respondents strongly agreed that they could not have attended YMC*A without funding.

The culture that YMC*A has developed is crucial to the success of the conference goal to create a space where participants can network, feel a sense of belonging, and are comfortable asking questions. Survey respondents' comments consistently said that having a conference dedicated to young researchers, with a focus on a nonthreatening conference culture and ample social time, made it easier for them to interact with other mathematicians and ask questions or discuss ideas. One remarked, ''The whole conference made it easier to interact with others, in particular the excursion where I met some new people not in my pre-existing network. It seemed like a lot of people were asking questions so I had no hesitation with asking."

Attending YMC*A has enhanced the participants' professional opportunities. In 2022, three of the NSF-funded participants were invited to give a talk and three other NSF-funded participants gave 3-minute "lightning" talks at YMC*A. Six of the 12 survey respondents who were NSF-funded participants reported that conversations at YMC*A inspired new ideas for research. The benefits from attending YMC*A are long-lasting: one NSF-funded participant remarked, "I found a collaborator! I was able to reconnect with someone who I had met previously and we are planning on working on a paper together."

Two new events were added to the YMC*A program this year: a Mentor Network breakfast for conference participants belonging to an underrepresented gender in mathematics, and an "Ask Anything" panel where participants could submit questions anonymously and experts answered those questions during a panel. All five of the women and non-binary NSF-funded participants attended the Mentor Network breakfast where issues in equity and a sense of belonging within the operator algebras community were discussed. One survey respondent commented, "The Ask Anything session led to a...discussion that KMS states were important in the study of C*-algebras... The discussion therefore gave me new insight into the tools used in other areas of operator algebras." Another said, "...the format of the conference makes interaction with other mathematicians easy...the Ask Anything session helped with this."

YMC*A 2022 featured twenty-one 25-minute research and eleven "lightning" talks by participants, a conference dinner, an afternoon of group excursions, and three minicourses from experts: Professor Xin Li spoke on "Groupoids and topological full groups," Lyudmila Turowska spoke on "Quantum correlations, non-local games, and operator algebras," and Sergey Neshveyev spoke on "Subproduct systems, associated C*-algebras, and their symmetries." The 2022 exit survey for NSF-funded participants included several comments evidencing the usefulness of the minicourses: one respondent said, "I had a discussion with Neshveyev at the dinner and it appears that there is some work to be done in terms of extending my research work to a much general question..." Another said, "I enjoyed Xin Li's talks and would like to investigate the topological full groups of some of the ample groupoids showing up in my research."

In general, YMC*A has a lasting effect on participants. One 2022 NSF-funded participant remarked, "I've attended in 2019 and 2021...I was able to meet Ian Putnam and he ended [up] being on my thesis defense committee." Another said, "Attending YMC*A has made me feel like a mathematician instead of a young graduate student. It makes me feel like there is a world-wide community full of people who have similar research interests to me, and it is very motivating to know this."
